briefdescription.para: Access macros.
Add a 32-bit integer value to a hash table.

detaileddescription.para: This macro is the clean way to do this and avoid compiler warnings on 64-bit platforms.

briefdescription.para: Replace a 32-bit integer value in a hash table.

detaileddescription.para: This macro is the clean way to do this and avoid compiler warnings on 64-bit platforms.

briefdescription.para: Enter a 32-bit integer value in a hash table.

detaileddescription.para: This macro is the clean way to do this and avoid compiler warnings on 64-bit platforms.

briefdescription.para: Replace a 32-bit integer value in a hash table.

detaileddescription.para: This macro is the clean way to do this and avoid compiler warnings on 64-bit platforms.

briefdescription.para: A note by ARCHAN at 20050510: Technically what we use is so-called "hash table with buckets" which is very nice way to deal with external hashing.

detaileddescription.para: There are definitely better ways to do internal hashing (i.e. when everything is stored in the memory.) In Sphinx 3, this is a reasonable practice because hash table is only used in lookup in initialization or in lookups which is not critical for speed. Another note by ARCHAN at 20050703: To use this data structure properly, it is very important to realize that the users are required to handle memory allocation of the C-style keys. The hash table will not make a copy of the memory allocated for any of the C-style key. It will not allocate memory for it. It will not delete memory for it. As a result, the following code sniplet will cause memory leak.

while (1){ str=(char*)ckd_calloc(str_length,sizeof(char*)) if(hash_enter(ht,str,id)!=id){ printf("fail to add key str %s with val id %d\n",str,id)} } A note by dhuggins on 20061010: Changed this to use void * instead of int32 as the value type, so that arbitrary objects can be inserted into a hash table (in a way that won't crash on 64-bit machines ;) The hash table structures. Each hash table is identified by a hash_table_t structure. hash_table_t.table is pre-allocated for a user-controlled max size, and is initially empty. As new entries are created (using hash_enter()), the empty entries get filled. If multiple keys hash to the same entry, new entries are allocated and linked together in a linear list.

briefdescription.para: In: Expected number of entries in the table
In: Whether case insensitive for key comparisons. When 1, case is insentitive, 0, case is sensitive.
Allocate a new hash table for a given expected size.

simplesect.para: Case sensitivity of hash keys applies to 7-bit ASCII characters only, and is not locale-dependent.

briefdescription.para: In: Handle of hash table to free
Free the specified hash table; the caller is responsible for freeing the key strings pointed to by the table entries.
In: Handle of hash table in which to create entry
In: C-style NULL-terminated key string for the new entry
In: Value to be associated with above key
Try to add a new entry with given key and associated value to hash table h.

detaileddescription.para: If key doesn't already exist in hash table, the addition is successful, and the return value is val. But if key already exists, return its existing associated value. (The hash table is unchanged; it is up to the caller to resolve the conflict.)

briefdescription.para: In: Handle of hash table in which to create entry
In: C-style NULL-terminated key string for the new entry
In: Value to be associated with above key
Add a new entry with given key and value to hash table h.

detaileddescription.para: If the key already exists, its value is replaced with the given value, and the previous value is returned, otherwise val is returned.

A very important but subtle point: The key pointer in the hash table is replaced with the pointer passed to this function. In general you should always pass a pointer to hash_table_enter() whose lifetime matches or exceeds that of the hash table. In some rare cases it is convenient to initially enter a value with a short-lived key, then later replace that with a long-lived one. This behaviour allows this to happen.

briefdescription.para: In: Handle of hash table in which a key will be deleted
In: C-style NULL-terminated key string for the new entry
Delete an entry with given key and associated value to hash table h.

detaileddescription.para: Return the value associated with the key (NULL if it did not exist)

briefdescription.para: In: Handle of hash table in which a key will be deleted
In: C-style NULL-terminated key string for the new entry
Like hash_table_delete, but with an explicitly specified key length, instead of a NULL-terminated, C-style key string.

detaileddescription.para: So the key string is a binary key (or bkey). Hash tables containing such keys should be created with the HASH_CASE_YES option. Otherwise, the results are unpredictable.

briefdescription.para: In: Handle of hash table
Delete all entries from a hash_table.
In: Handle of hash table in which to create entry
In: Key buffer
In: Length of above key buffer
In: Value to be associated with above key
Like hash_table_enter, but with an explicitly specified key length, instead of a NULL-terminated, C-style key string.

detaileddescription.para: So the key string is a binary key (or bkey). Hash tables containing such keys should be created with the HASH_CASE_YES option. Otherwise, the results are unpredictable.

briefdescription.para: In: Handle of hash table in which to create entry
In: Key buffer
In: Length of above key buffer
In: Value to be associated with above key
Like hash_table_replace, but with an explicitly specified key length, instead of a NULL-terminated, C-style key string.

detaileddescription.para: So the key string is a binary key (or bkey). Hash tables containing such keys should be created with the HASH_CASE_YES option. Otherwise, the results are unpredictable.

briefdescription.para: In: Handle of hash table being searched
In: C-style NULL-terminated string whose value is sought
Out: *val = value associated with key. If this is NULL, no value will be returned.
Look up a key in a hash table and optionally return the associated value.

simplesect.para: 0 if key found in hash table, else -1.

briefdescription.para: In: Handle of hash table being searched
In: C-style NULL-terminated string whose value is sought
Out: *val = value associated with key. If this is NULL, no value will be returned.
Look up a 32-bit integer value in a hash table.

detaileddescription.para: This function is the clean way to do this and avoid compiler warnings on 64-bit platforms.

briefdescription.para: In: Handle of hash table being searched
In: Key buffer
In: Length of above key buffer
Out: *val = value associated with key. If this is NULL, no value will be returned.
Like hash_lookup, but with an explicitly specified key length, instead of a NULL-terminated, C-style key string.

detaileddescription.para: So the key string is a binary key (or bkey). Hash tables containing such keys should be created with the HASH_CASE_YES option. Otherwise, the results are unpredictable.

briefdescription.para: In: Handle of hash table being searched
In: Key buffer
In: Length of above key buffer
Out: *val = value associated with key. If this is NULL, no value will be returned.
Look up a 32-bit integer value in a hash table.

detaileddescription.para: This function is the clean way to do this and avoid compiler warnings on 64-bit platforms.

briefdescription.para: Start iterating over key-value pairs in a hash table.
Get the next key-value pair in iteration.

detaileddescription.para: This function automatically frees the iterator object upon reaching the final entry.

simplesect.para: the next entry in the hash table, or NULL if done.

briefdescription.para: Delete an unfinished iterator.
In: Hash table from which list is to be generated
Out: Number of entries in the list. If this is NULL, no count will be returned.
Build a glist of valid hash_entry_t pointers from the given hash table.

detaileddescription.para: Return the list.

briefdescription.para: In: Hash table to display
In: Show the string or not, Use 0 if hash_enter_bkey was used.
Display a hash-with-chaining representation on the screen.

detaileddescription.para: Currently, it will only works for situation where hash_enter was used to enter the keys.

briefdescription.para: Hash table implementation.

detaileddescription.para: This hash tables are intended for associating a pointer/integer "value" with a char string "key", (e.g., an ID with a word string). Subsequently, one can retrieve the value by providing the string key. (The reverse functionalityobtaining the string given the valueis not provided with the hash table module.)
